values.alignmentText: Strong .NET demand in Ireland's Dublin tech scene; enterprise roles, startups, and visa-friendly paths for expats.
Ireland pay for 2D environmental artists generally aligns with EU medians after cost of living; Dublin offers strong dev scene and family-friendly cities.
2D environmental art CE in Ireland is mainly sporadic workshops and online courses. For a family move, remote options help keep skills sharp.
Ireland has multiple game-art programs (Dublin: NCAD, TU Dublin) feeding 2D environmental artists; a solid local pipeline.
In Ireland, 2D Environmental Artist hiring typically takes 3-4 months with proactive sourcing or relocation support; remote work eases talent pools.
Ireland's 2D environmental art scene is English-first; Gaelic is optional. English fluency is universal across studios.
Remote-friendly studios in Ireland widely support hybrid/remote 2D environmental art; Dublin and tech hubs offer flexible schedules for families.
Ireland's 2D environmental artist pool is solid, with Dublin/Cork studios and mid-to-senior talent; competition for seniors is noticeable.
Ireland (Dublin) 3D animator pay aligns with global medians after cost of living; solid packages and startup grants support family relocation.
In Ireland, 3D animation short courses run regularly via Animation Skillnet and colleges. Access to skilled instructors is solid.
Ireland has multiple animation programs (IADT, TU Dublin, Ballyfermot, GMIT) feeding well-prepared grads to local studios.
Ireland's 3D animator market (Dublin/Galway) typically 2-3 months with active sourcing. Niche talent may take longer.
In Ireland, 3D studios operate in English; Gaelic is a bonus but not required. English ubiquity fits your plan; you’re open to learning local language.
Ireland studios widely support hybrid/remote 3D animator roles, especially in Dublin and other tech hubs; some positions require periodic onsite days.
Moderate Ireland pool with core talent in Dublin; startups may need relocation or extended searches for senior 3D animators.
In Ireland, 3D character artist pay trails top hubs by ~25-30%; Dublin salaries are solid, with strong benefits and startup grants for founders.
Ireland offers 3D character art continuing education via Animation Skillnet and Dublin colleges; occasional courses and online options help keep skills sharp.
Ireland hosts multiple degree programs in animation and game art (Dublin, Galway, Limerick) that consistently graduate capable 3D character artists.
Expect 2-3 months to hire a 3D character artist in Ireland (Dublin tech hubs) due to limited specialist supply; remote hiring helps.
Across Ireland, 3D character art roles are English-dominant; Dublin/Cork studios expect strong English fluency; Gaelic knowledge optional.
Remote/hybrid 3D character artist roles are common in Ireland, especially around Dublin. Studios often provide equipment stipends and rely on strong broadband.
Moderate 3D character artist pool in Ireland; Dublin-area studios offer mid/senior talent, but startups may need relocation or extended searches.
Ireland has occasional game-focused accelerators. Dublin-based programs like NDRC/Enterprise Ireland offer grants, but dedicated game tracks are limited.
Ireland generally has good air quality. Occasional winter particulates from home heating in some areas.
Flagship AAA presence in Ireland (Riot Games Dublin) plus major service studios (Keywords, others) drive steady game/tech employment.
In Ireland (IE), secular culture is strong and atheism is broadly accepted. Expect minimal religious barriers in work and daily life.
Ireland's democracy is robust with independent judiciary and media. EU oversight adds strong checks against backsliding.
Banking in Ireland is modern with easy card payments; expect ID and address proof; PPSN helps. Fintechs like Revolut/Wise support cross-border use.
Irish beaches near Dublin and beyond offer scenic coastlines with mild summers; water’s chilly, but safe for kids with seasonal lifeguards and walks.
Ireland has active boardgaming scenes in Dublin and Galway, with FLGS, clubs, and Gaelcon/Warpcon; family-friendly for gamers.
In Ireland, body-image talk stays generally respectful. Maintain boundaries to protect Trey's and Anduin's confidence in school and sport.
Ireland's diverse tech scene and startup grants support quick reemployment; Dublin-area roles offer remote/hybrid paths for Trey & Sarah.
Ireland cancer incidence aligns with global norms. Robust screening and universal healthcare support routine checks.
In Ireland (IE), oversight by the Inspector of Prisons exists. Conditions are generally decent, with some facilities lagging in services and transparency.
IE's National Childcare Scheme subsidizes care; ECCE helps 3-5 year-olds; remaining costs for your 1-year-old still require planning and coordination.
Ireland is very kid-friendly: safe neighborhoods, parks, and strong family supports; English is dominant and the climate is mild.
Ireland's National Childcare Scheme substantially lowers fees for a working family with a 1- and 5-year-old. Some costs remain despite subsidies.
In Ireland, visa families can access NCS/ECCE, but require residency proof/PPSN; subsidies may have waiting periods and documentation checks.
In Ireland, clubs and venues for gaming, board games, climbing, and cycling help this family quickly find local, social activities.
Ireland offers frequent game dev and tech meetups with annual conferences (Dublin/Galway), plus grants; strong community for entrepreneurs.
Ireland offers readily available wellness resources and universal healthcare. You may still need to connect with like-minded circles to stay motivated.
In Ireland (IE), a few reputable co-living and cooperative options exist in Dublin and larger towns. Demand may require patience for families.
Ireland (Dublin): community manager pay lags top hubs 10-15%; strong benefits and visa options offset higher living costs.
Ireland, especially Dublin, offers regular CM meetups and short courses with solid instructors. Upskilling for community managers is reasonably accessible here.
Several strong degree programs in Dublin and other Irish cities feed well-prepared community manager grads annually; game/tech ecosystem is growing.
Ireland (Dublin) has a solid English-speaking pool; expect 2–3 months to hire a Community Manager amid competition.
In Ireland, English is dominant in community roles; some teams value Irish language awareness, but English suffices for most roles.
In Ireland, studios widely support flexible remote/hybrid work with async workflows. Equipment stipends and family-friendly schedules are common.
Solid community manager pool in Ireland, centered in Dublin's tech scene; senior CM roles are competitive, relocation or remote options may be needed.
In Ireland, newcomers find friendly locals, active clubs, and expat networks; communities weave families into city life with welcoming events.
In Ireland, established studios generally track global medians after cost of living; expect negotiation and solid benefits in Dublin.
In Dublin, Ireland, startup pay blends solid cash with equity. High living costs lift total comp, with clear equity norms and grant support.
Ireland: monitor 183-day tax residency; keep IRP renewals current and obtain a PPS number; private health insurance advised for timely care.
Ireland has regular tech bootcamps, meetups, and university courses. Dublin and other cities host game/tech programs suitable for Trey and Sarah.
Ireland has a healthy contractor bench for tech (Dublin/Cork); rapid onboarding is common, though top talent can book out for weeks.
Ireland's harm-reduction oriented system with robust health services supports treatment; penalties are relatively light.
Ireland offers strong startup grants and English-friendly admin, but Dublin rents and payroll costs are high; plan with incentives.
Housing/childcare pricey in Dublin; groceries/utilities around EU avg - budget tight but feasible with solid salaries and local discounts.
Ireland has quality coworking (Dublin and beyond) with a few shared game-production resources; strong startup grants support indie devs.
Ireland's tech market shows slight scarcity for Unity/.NET roles; competition remains. Remote work and visa pathways ease family transitions.
Ireland's universal healthcare and open mental health dialogue align with the family's needs; services are accessible though therapy wait times exist.
Depth grows steadily in Ireland with consistent effort. Join local clubs, school events, and community groups to build trust.
Ireland's D&I climate is solid: strong anti-discrimination laws, LGBTQ+ rights, and inclusive workplaces; expect steady progress and supportive communities.
Most enforcement in Ireland (IE) is targeted with occasional crackdowns. Overall safety remains solid for families.
Ireland (IE) allows dual citizenship with the US, usually via naturalization after residency; no renunciation required.
In Ireland, Enterprise Ireland and EU grants offer non-dilutive support for early-stage tech. Gaming startups can access them.
Ireland offers Enterprise Ireland and EU grants for early-stage game startups. Capital dedicated to games is modest, but general funds and grants exist.
Ireland offers solid fundamentals with low unemployment and steady growth; housing costs and inflation stress family budgets.
Ireland operates an open market with EU protections. It offers startup grants and a thriving tech ecosystem to back founders.
Ireland offers a stable policy environment with steady support for tech and creative industries. This predictability aids our game/tech startup plans.
Ireland offers solid English-language education with secular/multidenominational options. Urban Catholic schools can be oversubscribed, so plan ahead.
Ireland has a strong game-education pipeline in Dublin and Galway, with accredited programs and studio partnerships offering internships and capstone projects.
Visa sponsorship for ICT roles is common in Ireland, with fast Critical Skills processing. Dependents and relocation support are available in Dublin and major hubs.
Ireland hosts vibrant Unity and Unreal communities (Dublin/Cork) with active cross-pollination, meetups, and EU game-dev funding.
Ireland offers clean air and abundant green spaces. Easy access to coastlines and forests supports our family-friendly outdoors.
Ireland's two-earner tax mix (income tax + USC/PRSI) is around 30%. Strong public healthcare and education help offset costs.
Ireland in fall is mostly mild (9-14 C) with light sweater weather. October-November brings more rain and breezes.
Ireland's safe towns with parks and universal healthcare fit family priorities; mild climate supports outdoor time most days.
In Ireland, spouse and two minor children usually qualify for family reunification with modest steps; partner gets Stamp 4, kids on dependent visas.
Ireland provides 26 weeks maternity leave and 2 weeks paternity; Child Benefit is available. Access can involve forms and processing times.
Ireland offers strong family supports (child benefit, childcare subsidies); benefits vary by income and family status.
In Ireland, visa families have access to some social supports, but many benefits require habitual residence status and employer/PRSI-like contributions.
In Ireland, smart-casual is common in urban/work settings; Dublin areas lean neat but allow relaxed wear at home or family events.
Ireland’s fashion is inclusive and expressive; in Dublin and bigger towns women wear smart-casual, practical outfits with room for individuality.
Smart-casual with waterproof outerwear and sturdy boots for Irish rain. Versatile, city-ready layers fit Dublin life with understated, modern appeal.
In Ireland, progressive norms support diverse femininity; minor conservative pockets persist in some rural areas.
In Ireland, firearms are tightly regulated with strict licensing for sport and hunting. Ownership exists but is highly controlled and safety-focused.
In Ireland, consent culture is strong; flirting remains respectful with clear cues, and Irish venues reinforce boundaries.
Ireland's Dublin startup scene features large, experienced founder networks and active mentorship (Enterprise Ireland, hubs like Dogpatch Labs) supporting new teams.
Fresh markets and diverse restaurants are strong in Ireland's urban centers (Dublin, Cork). A few niche cuisines may require travel to regional cities.
In Ireland, locals are friendly and welcoming to newcomers. Expat and community groups help you connect within weeks.
Ireland offers game-dev grants via Enterprise Ireland and EU programs. With a strong plan, expect roughly €450k–€1.1M annually.
Dublin and Galway host a mid-sized game dev scene with indie and outsourcing roles. AAA studios are limited, so networking is key.
In Ireland's urban areas, gender-fluid identities are broadly accepted; some official documents lag behind practice.
Ireland offers strong gender rights protections and enforcement; parental leave improving; leadership representation still catching up.
In Ireland, gender roles are largely egalitarian, esp. in urban areas with strong work-life policies; rural areas may still show tradition.
In Ireland's urban centers, flirting norms are broadly modern; only minor lingering traditional cues remain in some circles.
Ireland visa life is stable but depends on work permits/renewals; GNIB/IRP, PPSN, and address proof required; rights vary by stamp.
Moderate warming expected; Ireland faces more heavy rain and coastal flooding, but mild summers and solid infrastructure keep risk manageable.
Ireland's Start-Up Entrepreneur Programme offers founder visas with grants via Enterprise Ireland; processing times are moderate.
Moderate grooming expected; Ireland's tech scene leans business-casual, so a neat, low-maintenance look fits work and community life.
In Ireland (IE), acceptance exists within progressive scenes and is tolerated publicly with respectful curiosity.
Ireland has universal public healthcare, but queues can be long. Many families use private insurance to shorten waits, including pediatric care.
Ireland (IE): visa families can access care but face extra paperwork and costs; private insurance is common.
Ireland offers Free Fees + SUSI grants; broad HE options in Dublin/Cork/Galway/Limerick; non-citizens may face international fees.
Ireland (IE): US visa holders pay international fees; scholarships are limited, but work and PR pathways improve with longer residence.
Ireland's Dublin/Galway game dev scene is small but active; expect ~3 months to fill established roles, visa steps can extend timelines; networking helps.
Ireland startup hiring is typically 1–2 months with active pipelines; EI/LEO support helps, aligning with our remote-friendly, grant-seeking plan.
Dublin rents in Ireland are high with limited stock; a 3-bed family home often exceeds €2k/month, with bidding and space compromises.
Tax in Ireland is largely digital (PAYE/ROS) with family credits; returns are pre-filled and guidance is clear for couples with kids.
Ireland is broadly welcoming to migrants; English ubiquity eases integration. Occasional debates on housing and cost of living temper sentiment overall.
Ireland generally welcomes US white migrants; English ubiquity aids integration. Minor stereotypes persist but are easy to navigate with local engagement.
Ireland offers broad access to public primary/secondary with largely free basics. Educate Together options are expanding, but top schools use catchments.
In Ireland, visa families can enroll in public K-12, but expect extra paperwork and proof of residence; English language supports are available.
English is widely used in Ireland; Irish is official, but daily life and services are mainly in English, with bilingual options.
In Ireland, English is widely used in studios; most docs are in English, with some Irish-language compliance needs.
In Ireland's startup scene, English dominates investor communications; Gaelic fluency supports regulatory tasks and community outreach.
Ireland (Dublin) has several IP/tech firms with game IP licensing know-how; startup-friendly pricing and EU protections.
Ireland-wide LGBTQ+ protections are strong; Dublin and major cities are inclusive, though some rural areas may be cautious.
Playtesting exists in Ireland (Dublin/Cork) via university labs and local gamer communities; schedule lead time.
Ireland's urban discourse treats Marxism as a niche but visible strand; left ideas influence debates without dominating policy.
In Ireland (IE), masculinity norms are broadly inclusive; caregiving is increasingly normalized, though some older circles hold traditional views.
In Ireland, incidents are uncommon; authorities communicate transparently and communities feel prepared.
Ireland's Dublin-area meetups offer frequent tech/game dev, parenting, and LGBTQ+ groups; poly scenes exist but stay low-profile.
In Dublin, Ireland, the minimum wage is around €12.70/hour. It trails the living wage (~€14/hour) and can't comfortably cover housing or childcare.
In Ireland, cities offer fast broadband and widespread contactless payments. The power grid is reliable and e-governance is solid, though rural areas lag.
In Ireland, urban hubs like Dublin are welcoming to non-monogamy; rural areas require discretion.
IE's open society supports direct, constructive dialogue; transparency and civil liberties are valued, with pluralistic media and inclusive communities.
Stunning Irish coastlines and lakes are within easy reach; family-friendly trails around Wicklow/Dublin offer frequent day trips.
Natural hazards in Ireland are rare and typically low impact. Atlantic storms may occur, but building standards and warnings keep families safe.
Great nature access in Ireland: Wicklow Mountains and coastline within easy reach from Dublin by rail or car; many family-friendly trails and parks.
Ireland has robust live music and pub culture with year-round festivals. Many daytime events and family-friendly options exist in Dublin, Cork, and Galway.
Nightlife exists in Dublin, Cork, Galway; pubs with live music, late bars. For families, earlier-evening options are common; plan sitters and transport.
Imirt - Irish Game Makers (Ireland) runs regular meetups and online hubs; welcoming families and newcomers to the Ireland game dev scene.
Dublin, Ireland hosts Keywords Studios, Vela Games, WarDucks and indie studios; a robust game ecosystem for a family-focused tech move.
In Ireland, obesity is moderate. Active transport and public health programs help keep trends stable for our family.
Strong Ireland game startup support via EI/LEO, New Frontiers, Imirt; Dublin grants and networks help launch studios.
Dublin can be fast and pricey; Cork/Galway pace is more relaxed, easing daily routines. Ireland outside Dublin supports better work-life balance.
Ireland offers empathetic parenting support and common paternal leave; schools partner with families.
Ireland naturalisation usually after 5 years' reckonable residence in 9 years (with 1 year continuous); dual citizenship allowed.
Perceived corruption in Ireland is low by EU standards. Strong rule of law and watchdogs support transparent public services.
In Ireland, most locals read body language well; busy urban areas (Dublin, etc.) can feel closer than preferred, guiding personal boundaries.
In Ireland, crowded transit exists; people respect personal space, check before touching, and back off if you signal discomfort.
Ireland (IE) offers two to three mild seasons with comfortable temps; expect rain in shoulder months, so plan for layers.
Ireland uses a parliamentary system with PR-STV and coalitions. Reforms occur through open civic channels and strong courts uphold rights.
In Ireland (Dublin/Cork), polyamory is visible and tolerated. No legal recognition yet, so discretion helps with schools and immigration.
Ireland offers 2 years of free ECCE pre-school with NCS subsidies; urban waitlists and costs vary, so plan early for care.
Private/international schools exist in Ireland's cities (Dublin/Cork); fees are high and capacity is tight; secular options exist; verify accreditation.
In Ireland, processed foods are common, but strong local markets balance meals with fresh produce.
Ireland (Dublin) PMM (Games) pay is near global medians after cost of living; packages often include bonuses/equity; remote/hybrid options common.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Ireland's game scene (Dublin area) has few dedicated PMM (Games) programs; expect sporadic workshops and online courses; most upskilling is self-directed.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Ireland has marketing/tech programs in Dublin. Studio partnerships exist, but dedicated PMM (Games) curricula are scarce, so on-the-job upskilling is common.
Ireland (Dublin): PMM (Games) roles typically 3-4 months; solid tech ecosystem, but niche talent may require proactive sourcing or relocation.
Ireland: English is widely used in games marketing. Local Irish language knowledge is a plus but not required.
Ireland game PM remote expectations: most studios offer flexible remote/hybrid work; EU-friendly hours and visa/grant support align with this family.
Moderate pool in Ireland (Dublin) for game product marketing. Strong tech scene and EU access, but senior PMMs may need relocation or remote options.
Progressive ideas thrive in Ireland's major cities (Dublin, Cork) with strong LGBTQ+ rights and abortion access. Rural areas temper national debates.
In Ireland, progressive sex-positive norms support adult relationships with minimal policing. Casual dating is broadly accepted; some traditional circles gossip.

In Ireland (IE), media is broadly free; watchdogs/public broadcasters debunk spins, and diverse outlets keep messaging balanced.
In Ireland, Dublin's buses, Luas, and DART are usable, but delays and evening coverage gaps mean a backup car is wise for family errands.

Ireland offers family-friendly towns with good schools and healthcare, but premium services and clubs can require planning due to demand.
In Ireland, universal healthcare covers basics, but housing and childcare remain costly, pressuring savings for a two-kid family.
Ireland offers solid QoL for a two-adult, two-kid family with universal healthcare and strong schools; Dublin-area housing is a major cost.

Ireland is largely secular; religion shapes culture but policy remains pluralistic and rights-protective, with some church influence in schools.
Hybrid/remote roles are standard in Ireland's established studios, with clear policies, aligning with your family-friendly, English-friendly setup.
Ireland's startup scene favors hybrid work with strong remote tooling, matching Sarah and Trey's needs; grants and visa routes support founders.
Remote and hybrid work are common in Ireland. Dublin and other cities offer coworking spaces and strong broadband for Trey, Sarah, and remote teams.
Stamps (1/1G/4); In Ireland (Dublin), Critical Skills can lead to Stamp 4 after a period; GEP longer; entrepreneurship routes available.
Ireland's stable tech scene and grants support long tenures; English ubiquity and family-friendly policies reduce churn, though project cycles may spike.
In Ireland, State Pension (Contributory) starts around 66 with PRSI. Private pensions are common, and EU portability supports cross-border retirement planning.
In Ireland, pension access depends on PRSI contributions. Visa holders face residency thresholds, so private retirement savings become central.
Ruby roles exist but cluster in a few Irish startups. Network regularly in Dublin and via remote gigs for steady opportunities.
Generally safe in Ireland; petty theft in crowded city cores (e.g., Dublin); unrest is rare. Exercise normal after-dark precautions.
Ireland has English‑medium public schools with non‑denominational and bilingual options; Catholic patronage remains common; expect catchment-based placement.
In Ireland, sea water stays cool; most of the year 15–18 C; summer may need light wetsuits for kids.
Ireland's temperate climate brings mild seasons with regular rain. Expect a few stormy weeks per season, but overall manageable variability for family life.
In Ireland, winter daylight is limited; stay energized with regular outdoor breaks and occasional light therapy.
Ireland's oceanic climate: mild summers, cool winters, frequent rain. Long summer days, short winter daylight; rain gear recommended for outdoor plans.
Ireland's Dublin/Cork tech scene has an adequate pool of senior leaders with startup experience; expect competitive offers.
Ireland is broadly liberal; sex education is comprehensive nationwide, with urban areas more open, though rural norms may vary.
Ireland offers strong anti-discrimination and LGBTQ+ protections with universal healthcare and family supports; newcomer access and housing waits may need outreach.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: 2k sq ft rentals exist mainly in Dublin and commuter towns, but listings are tight. Expect fast competition and higher rents.
In Ireland, spring is mild and damp. Most days feel comfortable, with occasional cool or windy spells requiring light jackets.
Stable democracy and pro-business Ireland; predictable policies and peaceful transitions with low protest risk for a family relocating from the US.
Ireland's liberal, rights-respecting democracy aligns with a progressive, family-friendly lifestyle and strong entrepreneurship support.
Ireland's dynamic, regulated market with startup grants and strong safety nets fits the family; English-speaking, welcoming communities and Dublin's tech scene.
Ireland has a modest but growing game-dev scene, centered in Dublin with several indie studios and supportive grants.
Ireland (IE): summers typically 18-22°C days with cool evenings; on rare hot spells it may reach ~25-27°C, nights stay well under 20°C.
In Ireland, most interactions are warm and upbeat; locals respond positively to friendly initiations. Expect polite, cheerful exchanges in Dublin and beyond.
Ireland's Section 481/interactive media credits cover games with clear eligibility and timely payouts via Screen Ireland and Enterprise Ireland.
IE entrepreneur visas can take months; budget for up to ~9 months and moderate fees. Premium options exist; gather strong docs for a family move.
Trust in government in Ireland is generally high. Transparent, responsive services ease visas, healthcare, and daily life.
Ireland (IE) shows low, well-managed corruption: mostly petty/procurement issues with strong oversight and quick corrective action.
Irish tech pay, especially in Dublin, is high relative to living costs; dual software careers support a comfortable Dublin lifestyle with remote options.
Weekends in Ireland offer parks, markets, and family-friendly events. Most venues allow spontaneous visits, though popular spots may book up.

Ireland offers 4 weeks (20 days) of paid leave plus public holidays (about 9 days). This suits family time for Trey and Sarah.

Ireland (Dublin region) has several reputable vendors for overflow in art, QA, and engineering; supportive grants boost outsourcing viability.
In Ireland (Dublin), compensation for real-time VFX aligns with global medians after cost-of-living adjustments; strong tech demand supports stable packages.
Irish VFX real-time education is intermittent; mostly visiting experts or remote courses. Dublin and Galway offer some short programs, but broader local options are limited.
VFX (real-time) education in Ireland benefits from several programs (TU Dublin, IADT) feeding Dublin studios. Graduates are well-prepared for local studios.
Ireland (Dublin) VFX real-time roles typically 3-4 months; active sourcing or relocation support improves timelines.
In Ireland (IE), English is dominant in VFX real-time studios; Dublin and Cork hubs support multilingual collaboration.
IE VFX real-time roles trend hybrid/remote; Dublin studios support flexible work, with periodic onsite collaboration, aligned with your family-friendly policies.
Moderate Ireland VFX (Real-Time) talent pool; startups may need relocation or remote hires to access senior skills.
Ireland's view is pro-EU and cooperative with neighbors; UK ties are nuanced post-Brexit, but cross-border links remain strong.
In Ireland, we present a balanced, open self-view, proud to adapt and learn locally. We value education, healthcare, and a welcoming community.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors see Ireland as welcoming and stable with strong EU ties. Brexit tensions with the UK exist, but cooperation remains solid.
Ireland offers Critical Skills/GEP and startup routes via Enterprise Ireland; you likely qualify, but most paths require a job offer or startup funding.
In Ireland, many urban neighborhoods offer walkable streets with safe crossings. Plan routes to avoid busy arterials, especially near Dublin suburbs.
In Ireland (IE), US migrants are well-received; Dublin's startup ecosystem and clear visa routes (e.g., Critical Skills) ease relocation and business.
Rich literature and a growing Dublin tech scene with startup grants keep curiosity alive. English ubiquity supports family life.
Winters in Ireland are mild: days ~4-8 C; subfreezing nights rare; snow is uncommon outside uplands; heating costs manageable.
IE typical full-time is ~39-40h; strong work-life balance supported by family-friendly policies and remote options in Ireland.
IE: EU leave norms and flexible hours vary by employer; many tech firms in Ireland support boundaries, but peak projects can require extra hours.
Ireland follows EU labor protections; strong unions and clear termination rules; gig economy gaps remain; non-competes are limited.
